Consider a complex function \\( z(t) \\) defined in the complex plane, governed by the equation \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = i\\omega z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a real constant. We investigate the effect of an integral transformation \\( g(z) = \\int_0^T e^{i\\omega t} z(t) dt \\) over the interval [0, T].

If a new function \\( h(z) = \\int_{t_1}^{T} e^{i\\omega t}z(t) dt \\) (where \\( t_1 < T \\)) is applied as an intervention at \\( t_1 \\), will the function \\( z(T) \\) at the endpoint \\( T \\) depend only on the original differential equation and not on the transformations?
Explanation: The intervention \\( h(z) \\) introduces a new scope of integral transformation starting from \\( t_1 \\) to \\( T \\), affecting the trajectory and final expression of \\( z \\) by adding influences unique to the interaction between \\( e^{i\\omega t} \\) and the evolving function. This makes \\( z(T) \\) dependent on both the original dynamics and the new transformation.
